5079022.majtheme: Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. The lessons drawn from the
            implementation of the project: 1) Good preparation, and
            identification of the Borrower's implementing and
            financial capacity, were key to the success of the project.
            In addition, direct lending to a well-structured
            institution, Office for Port Management (ODEP) rather than
            on-lending to that institution by the Government, enhanced
            ODEP's ownership of the project and facilitated
            cooperation between the Bank and ODEP. 2) Close cooperation
            between the Bank and the Borrowers during identification,
            preparation, and supervision of the project ensured that the
            project responded to the Borrowers' needs, that the
            process of problem solving enhanced Borrowers' skills,
            and that it reinforced their ownership of the project. 3)
            Regarding the outcome of the Vessel Traffic Service
            component, it can be concluded that the budgetary and
            technical responsibility for a subproject involving several
            departments should preferably be assigned to a single
            entity, and the project unit and its manager should be
            identified at appraisal stage. 4) Trade facilitation is too
            complex to be handled in a sub-sector project, unless a
            process is defined at appraisal, responsibilities are
            clearly apportioned, the objective is actively endorsed by
            key players, and private sector constituencies already favor
            the reforms.

5079025.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Trade and integration

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objectives are to: (a)
            improve operational efficiency in the ports: (b) assist the
            government in strengthening the economic viability of its
            investments in the port subsector; and (c) encourage
            policies and institutional measures.  The project consists
            of an investment component and an institutional development
            component.  The investment component finances: (a) selected
            subprojects of the Office of Port Operations (ODEP's)
            investment program for the period 1991-1993; (b) a portion
            of the investment and maintenance program of the Ministry of
            Public Works (MPW) for the period 1991-1993; and (c)
            construction of a radar control tower for marine security.
            Selected subprojects specifically include:  (i) a new
            container terminal at Casablanca; (ii) a coal handling
            facility at Jorf Lasfar; (iii) improved Ro-Ro facilities at
            Tangier; (iv) equipment for port security; and (v) technical
            assistance and training.  MPW's program focuses
            entirely on rehabilitation of breakwaters and dredging.  The
            Development Programs of the port provide a comprehensive
            time-bound framework for monitoring the key institutional
            development objectives with particular reference to: (a)
            quality and efficiency of port services; (b) trade
            facilitation; (c) investment planning; (d) environment and
            safety; and (e) finance.
